stories.text: Begin using last.fm. I am a junior in high school.
Listen to a lot of Portugal. The Man. They remind me of physics class.
Enter a student film festival with my friend Mike. Listen to the first 30 seconds of The Vanishing by Stars at least 100 times during editing.
Start hanging out with a bunch of people I went to middle school with. These friends become some of the few people I keep in touch with during college.
My highest monthly play count for the band Metric occurs. Buy tickets to see them next month; my first real concert.
Begin dating a girl. 'Our' song is International Rock Star by Stars.
Take a summer class at Otis in LA. Anthem of the summer: West Coast by Coconut Records.
Return home to Ellicott City, MD.
Senior year of high school starts.
SATs, APs, and college applications stress me out. Muse seems to be the coping mechanism.
Break up with said girl. Listen to Stars a bunch, then stop listening to Stars for a while.
Last Christmas while living at home.
College applications end. Stress levels decrease dramatically.
My music player lives on shuffle, so I have no consistent trends for a month.
My friend gives me a mix tape. My favorite track on it is Take Care by Beach House, which I play about twice a day. The mix CD is still in my car.
Get into Penn. Go to prom(s).
Graduate high school. Vitamin C tells me we will always be friends forever. Play a lot of video games with my friends; we are dubbed the 'HoN Team'.
Start rock climbing as a hobby. Hear about Mumford and Sons from a friend from Otis and think I'm hip, then hear them a few weeks later at the climbing gym. Disappointed I'm not hip.
Start listening to Stars again. It took that long? That's embarassing. As Tall As Lions, a previous favorite, disappears from my listening history.
Summer draws to a close.
Start at Penn as a Digital Media Design major. Listen to a lot of Arcade Fire the first week of classes.
The month of concerts: I see Stars and Margot back to back, followed by Local Natives and Ingrid Michaelson two weeks later.
My friends agree Margot's new sound isn't as good as their first album; the most pretentious statement ever thought up by a couple of 18-year olds is made.
Get grades back for first semester. Realize I'm now a small fish in a big pond.
Spring semester of freshman year starts. Life is strange in the Quad. Listening habits remain pretty much consistent.
Begin applying for summer internships. Have little luck.
Current obsession: You're the One That I Want by Angus & Julia Stone.
Music plays go down as work picks up.
Reunite with the only person I still talk to from my high school. She introduces me to Noah and the Whale.
Start work at Dogpatch Films in San Francisco, where I spend half my time making their website and half my time holding a boom.
Anthem of the summer: No Children by The Mountain Goats.
End my internship with an intense hatred for cross-browser compatibility.
Return to Penn for sophomore year. Now really into Noah and the Whale.
Meet the new freshman DMD class at a Halloween party. Feel old. I get Beirut's recently released The Rip Tide and listen to it nonstop.
Compete in my first PennApps. We make 'Pandora for beer'.
Spend a lot of time modeling the ship Serenity for 3D modeling. Smooth listening like Joe Hisaishi and Radical Face make a resurgence.
Spring semester of sophomore year starts. Hack in my second PennApps.
Discover Walk off the Earth; listen to 3 of their covers a total of 180 combined times in one month.
I spend a lot of time trying to programmatically draw a cube on my screen in CIS 277. I spend all my time programming with Emancipator or Joe Hisaishi on in the background.
Busiest semester yet nears completion.
Begin a software internship at Washington Post Labs. Margot, statistically my #2 band of all time, gets a single, solitary play.
Split my time between DC and Maryland. Of Monsters and Men reminds me of the DC metro.
Begin semester abroad in Dunedin, New Zealand. Listens to Margot spike as my flatmate shows me an album of live recordings I haven't heard before.
Visit Australia for a week. Get caught in a snowstorm on top of Mount Wellington before spending some time in Melbourne and Sydney.
Drive 8 hours from Dunedin to Kaikoura for a seafood festival. Listen to The National the entire way back.
Spend the best 3 days of my life climbing and lazing in Wanaka. A couchsurfer named Henry sings a very good rendition of Just A Boy and rekindles my interest in Angus & Julia Stone.
Backpacking the North and South islands. Joe Hisaishi and The Antlers help me fall asleep in hostels.
Return to the US. Ecstatic to see friends from home over winter break. I listen to nothing but Radical Face and Lana Del Rey. No regrets.
Spring semester of junior year begins at Penn.
